messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-30T15:16:02Z
## Message ID: 20170330-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first crossed the 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-03-28T15:00Z (see notification 20170328-AL-002). Electron flux levels have remained elevated and crossed the 10^5 pfu threshold most recently at 2017-03-30T14:20Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-03-27T00:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-03-28T15:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-27T12:20:26Z
## Message ID: 20170327-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-03-27T09:00Z to 2017-03-27T12:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-03-27T00:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-03-27T09:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-25T14:26:46Z
## Message ID: 20170325-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-03-23T11:30Z (see recent notification 20170323-AL-002). The electron flux exceeded this threshold yesterday and remains elevated today at around 79,000 pfu, though below the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2017-03-21T00:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-03-23T11:30:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 15, 2017 - March 21, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-22T21:21:00Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-03-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170322-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  No CMEs traveling at speeds above 500 km/s were observed during the period.      

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-03-21T15:00Z-21:00Z.  This slight enhancement of the geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around the beginning of 2017-03-21.  Currently solar wind speeds have reached values of >700 km/s on 2017-03-22.  

On 2017-03-18 STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  Solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-03-18.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-03-28T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the next reporting period. There are some active regions on the far side and the active region 12643 visible on the west side of the solar disk as seen by the SDO AIA instrument that have the capability of producing some solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity has been high starting on 2017-03-21 due to the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  The energetic electron fluxes are already starting to increase to values 65,000 pfu and they will probably cross the threshold of 10^5 pfu in the next few days.   


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 08, 2017 - March 14, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-15T21:01:55Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-03-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170315-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.   No CMEs traveling at speeds above 500 km/s were observed at the available coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-03-08T21:00Z to 2017-03-09T03:00Z, 2017-03-10T06:00Z-12:00Z, and 2017-03-12T03:00Z-06:00Z.  

On 2017-03-11 STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream.  Solar wind speed reached values of >500 km/s on 2017-03-14.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to the continuing effects of the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-03-01 (see notifications 20170308-AL-001 and 20170311-AL-001).  After 2017-03-11, the fluxes have remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-03-21T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the next reporting period. There are some active regions on the far side as seen on the STEREO A EUVI images that have the capability of producing some solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity has slightly increased on 2017-03-15 due to the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream.  Solar wind speeds have remained around 400 km/s.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is approaching 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-03-11T13:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2017-03-01T06:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-03-02T14:05:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 01, 2017 - March 07, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-08T18:35:06Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-03-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170308-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-03-01T21:00Z to 2017-03-02T00:00Z.  This moderate increase in geomagnetic activity was associated to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around the beginning of the day of 2017-03-01.  The solar wind speed reached values of >750 km/s on 2017-03-04.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-03-02T14:05Z, and has remained elevated crossing the threshold several times during the reporting period (see notifications 20170302-AL-001, 20170302-AL-002, 20170304-AL-001, 20170306-AL-001, and 20170308-AL-001.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-03-14T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the next reporting period. There are some active regions on the solar disk that have the capability of producing some solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity has been decreasing on the last few days, but the energetic electron fluxes at the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 are still currently elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu (see notification 20170308-AL-001).


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 22, 2017 - February 28, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-03-01T23:40:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-02-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170301-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-02-24T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-02-23.  Solar wind speeds reached values of >650 km/s on 2017-02-24.  

The IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments at STEREO A detected the arrival of a couple small coronal hole high speed streams around 2017-02-26 and 2017-02-27.  The solar wind speed reached values >550 km/s on 2017-02-28. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-03-07T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the next reporting period. The geomagnetic activity is expected to be enhanced for the upcoming reporting due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-03-01.  Solar wind speeds are currently detected by DSCOVR at L1 to be around >650km/s on 2017-03-01.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
